Quantum entanglement swapping.<[silence]> Non-local correlations.<[silence]> Quantum teleportation.<[silence]>

Entanglement swapping is a quantum phenomenon where two particles, previously unentangled, become entangled through the interaction of a third pair of entangled particles.<[silence]> This process involves two pairs of particles, say A-B and C-D, where A and B, as well as C and D, are initially entangled.<[silence]> By performing a joint Bell-state measurement on particles B and C, the entanglement is effectively "swapped" to particles A and D, even though they have never interacted directly.<[silence]>

The significance of entanglement swapping lies in its ability to extend quantum entanglement over larger distances, a foundational principle for quantum communication networks.<[silence]> It enables the creation of entangled states between distant particles, facilitating the development of quantum repeaters, which are essential for long-distance quantum communication.<[silence]> This technique also plays a pivotal role in quantum teleportation, where the state of a quantum system is transferred from one location to another without physical transmission of the system itself.<[silence]>

The experimental realization of entanglement swapping requires precise control over quantum systems and accurate measurement techniques.<[silence]> Advances in photonic technology and quantum optics have enabled the successful demonstration of this phenomenon in laboratory settings, paving the way for practical applications.<[silence]> The ability to manipulate entanglement in this manner is a testament to the non-classical nature of quantum mechanics and its potential to revolutionize information processing.<[silence]>

Three related subjects are quantum cryptography, quantum repeaters, and quantum key distribution.<[silence]>
